blocks.text: Here we define assumptions only from the frontend point of view. We assume there is a stable backend API for creating short URLs and fetching link data. Our job is to design a fast, simple, accessible web UI on top of that API.

blocks.title: Product / UX assumptions
items: Users can create short links either as guests or logged-in users.
Core screens: Create Link (form), My Links list, Link Details / basic analytics.
We only support a simple custom alias field and optional expiry date selector.
Admin-only features (hard delete, force-disable) can be separate screens or hidden behind feature flags.
We do not build a full BI dashboard — only lightweight charts/tables for basic stats.

blocks.title: Platform & device assumptions
items: Primary target: modern evergreen browsers (Chrome, Edge, Firefox, Safari).
We do not support IE or very old mobile browsers.
UI must be responsive: desktop-first design that also works well on phone-sized viewports.
No native mobile app; this is a single-page web app (SPA) or MPA with a shared design system.
Accessibility: keyboard navigation, proper labels, focus states, and readable contrast.

items.label: Time to usable UI
items.helperText: On a decent network (e.g. 4G / home Wi-Fi)

items.label: API round-trip budget
items.helperText: For create + basic list fetch in normal conditions

blocks.title: API / data shape assumptions (from FE view)
items: Backend exposes simple REST or JSON APIs (e.g. POST /links, GET /links, GET /links/:id).
Each link has: id/token, originalUrl, shortUrl, createdAt, expiresAt, isActive, clickCount.
Analytics endpoints are paginated; frontend will not receive millions of rows at once.
Rate limits are enforced on the server, but frontend must handle 429 gracefully (e.g. friendly message and retry hint).
Auth (if any) is cookie or token-based; frontend just attaches the token and handles 401/403 states.

blocks.title: State management & caching constraints
items: Frontend keeps a local cache of recently created links so the user sees instant feedback after creation (optimistic update).
Large tables (My Links) are fetched page-by-page or with infinite scroll, not all at once.
We rely on client-side caching library (e.g. React Query / SWR / NgRx Query) or a simple custom cache; no complex offline mode.
Hard refresh should always be safe: all critical data is refetched from the API.
We avoid storing sensitive data (tokens, access keys) in localStorage except for non-sensitive session info.

blocks.title: Error, loading & empty-state assumptions
items: All API calls show clear loading states (spinner or skeleton) and never leave the user guessing.
Form validation errors (invalid URL, alias already taken) are shown inline, near the field.
Network errors show a generic, friendly message with a retry button.
Empty states are explicit: "You have no links yet" instead of a blank page.
Errors are logged to an error tracking tool (e.g. Sentry) from the frontend.

blocks.title: Security & UX guardrails (frontend only)
items: We always treat user-entered URLs as plain text; we never render them as HTML to avoid XSS.
All external links use rel="noopener noreferrer" and open in a new tab only when it makes sense.
We show a small warning badge for suspicious or HTTP-only (non-HTTPS) destinations if backend flags them.
We never expose internal admin flags or internal IDs directly in the UI.
We protect critical actions with confirmation (e.g. disabling a popular link).

blocks.title: Common frontend pitfall
blocks.text: Pushing heavy analytics scripts or visualizations into the main "Create" page can slow down the core flow. Keep the link creation path light and defer heavy charts to secondary views.
